Award.AwardTitle: EXP: "Earthquake Rebuild" - Mathematical Thinking and Learning via Architectural Design and Modeling

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this Cyberlearning: Transforming Education Exploration project, the PIs investigate how to help middle schoolers simultaneously develop mathematics understanding, mathematics skill, and mathematics disposition. They are taking design-based pedagogical approach, having students practice the math they are learning through architectural design. Their software environment, called "Earthquake Rebuild," sets learners up in a virtual environment where an earthquake has demolished a city, and they must use geometry and arithmetic to make architectural and city planning decisions as they aim to rebuild the city. In this same context software context, the investigators are incorporating means of unobtrusive collection and analysis of performance data, called "stealth assessment," for purposes of both tracking development of understanding and capabilities and providing adaptive learner support. Research addresses practical issues in design of systems that help learners deeply learn content and skills in the context of solving real-world problems and in design of stealth assessments. Research also addresses conceptual issues in mathematics learning, specifically focusing on the ways that informal mathematical conjectures emerge and are transformed into formal mathematics knowledge through concrete application.

Too many middle schoolers fail to develop the kinds of mathematics capabilities they will need to be productive in the workforce and to be engaged citizens. Even more middle schoolers complete middle school without appreciating the connections between mathematics and the real world they live in. The aim of this project is to address both of these issues: to promote deep mathematical understanding and capabilities among middle schoolers and to engage them in "mathematizing" their worlds -- seeing the roles mathematics plays in the natural and built environment around them. To achieve these goals, investigators are designing a software environment that allows students to combine serious play and learning as they use middle-school mathematics to reconstruct a demolished fictional city. The system is being designed to collect data about student understanding in the background (called "stealth assessment") so that as students engage with the system, it can help them use mathematics to rebuild the buildings in the fictional city, more deeply learn the mathematics they are using, and come to appreciate the usefulness of mathematics and mathematical thinking in engaging productively in problem solving and design activities. Investigators will learn more about how to design learning technologies that will help learners learn and appreciate mathematics, how mathematics is learned when students engage more systematically in using math, and how to accomplish the types of stealth assessment needed to personalize learning technologies to the needs of individual students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this Cyberlearning exploration project, we designed and developed a game-based mathematical software environment called “Earthquake Rebuild” (or E-Rebuild). Taking a learning-by-making pedagogical approach, this three-dimensional software environment engages middle school students in mathematical learning and practices through architectural design and building. This game-based software environment also incorporates the means of unobtrusive collection and analysis of the performance data to track and assess the development of math competencies. Research has addressed both practical and conceptual issues about learning with technology by (a) exploring the design of a play-based learning system that promotes mathematical meaning-making and skill development in the context of solving real-world problems, and (b) informing the design and practice of unobtrusive learning assessment in a highly interactive learning environment.

 

We conducted multiple empirical studies to examine the feasibility and effectiveness of E-Rebuild in helping students learn and appreciate mathematics, and to investigate the functional relationship between E-Rebuild’s design and implementation features and its learning effectiveness. The study results indicate the feasibility of using E-Rebuild in both school and after-school settings, both online and offline. We also found that using E-Rebuild has promoted formal mathematical knowledge development, positive mathematics dispositions, and potential spatial ability development of middle-school users. Through the studies, a conceptual framework describing how to effectively design and implement future digital game-based learning environments has been proposed, refined, and validated. The core mechanism for the integral development of game-based learning tasks and task-based, unobtrusive performance assessment has also been created, iteratively tested, and validated. Thus the project helped to lay the groundwork for a fuller account of how, when, and why a digital game-based learning system can be designed and implemented as a learning and an assessment tool. The project also makes intellectual contributions by helping us understand how to accomplish the types of unobtrusive assessment that will be needed for the future design of dynamic learning supports in technology-based learning environments.

 

Frequently, middle school students lack appreciation of the connections between mathematics and real-world problem solving, and fail to develop the necessary mathematics capabilities or skills to be productive in the workforce and to be engaged citizens. This project helped to address these issues by (a) promoting deep mathematical understanding and problem solving skills of middle school students, and (b) engaging them in conceptualizing and reasoning with daily-life scenarios and problems mathematically. The developed software environment is accessible, can be used online or downloaded for offline usage, and is compatible with low-end computers. Notably, the empirical study findings did not indicate gender difference or a moderation effect of prior gaming experiences on E-Rebuild users’ learning outcomes, supporting the viability of using E-Rebuild for diverse learners.
